clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Music Therapy on Breastfeeding Among Mothers of Premature Newborns
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial to Evaluate the Effects of Music Therapy on Breastfeeding Rates Among Mothers of Premature Newborns

lead_sponsor.agency: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

collaborator.agency: Instituto de Puericultura e Pediatria Martagão Gesteira

clinical_study.source: Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of music therapy on breastfeeding rates among mothers of premature newborns.
Hypothesis: Music therapy applied to mothers of premature newborns increases the rates of maternal breastfeeding at the time of the infant hospital discharge and at follow-up visits.

detailed_description.textblock: Music therapy has been shown to have positive effects in several areas such as mental health, special education, rehabilitation and social development. Its use as a means to facilitate communication and expression of emotional contents was shown to be able to promote relief of anxiety, fears and tensions. However, in the maternal and child health area there are still few studies demonstrating the contribution of this therapy in the promotion of health and no study evaluating specifically the impact of this intervention on the rates of breastfeeding in mothers of premature newborns.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At the time of the infant hospital discharge
At the first follow-up visit (7-15 days after discharge)

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal Breastfeeding at 30 Days After Discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 30 days after the infant hospital discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal Breastfeeding at 60 Days After Discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 60 days after the infant hospital discharge

intervention.description: Music therapy sessions systematically offered to all mothers in the intervention group, three times a week, not mandatory, conducted by two music therapists in an appropriate room, during 60 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Mothers of premature newborns, with birth weight ≤ 1750 g that have reached clinical stability defined by the medical staff.
- To have signed an informed consent to participate in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mothers that are HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) positive.
- Mothers of neonates with clinical problems that impaired breast suction (encephalopathy with serious hypotonus, oro-facial anomalies, and heart problems).
- Mothers with severe hearing deficiencies.
Exit Criteria:
- Mothers whose neonates died during the hospital stay.
- Mothers who, for any reason, had three or less music therapy sessions.

responsible_party.organization: Department of Pediatris, UFRJ School of Medicine

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment period: 03/01/2004 to 07/31/2007. Mothers of LBW newborns (≤ 1750g) that have reached clinical stability and signed an informed consent.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Eligible mothers: 190. Excluded: 89 (26 because their neonates fullfiled one of the exclusion criteria, 18 because their newborns died before being considered in clinical stability, 11 because they did not agree to participate and 34 because they could not be accessed during the newborn hospital stay, most for receiving early hospital discharge).

drop_withdraw_reason.title: 3 newborns died; 1 mother quit the study

outcome.title: Maternal Breastfeeding at Infant Discharge
outcome.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).
outcome.time_frame: At the time of the infant hospital discharge

measure.title: Maternal Breastfeeding at Infant Discharge
measure.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: Music therapy does not increase the rate of maternal breastfeeding. Sample size: considering 75% as the expected rate at the time of the infant hospital discharge and an absolute difference of 30% between groups, 95% confidence level (5% alpha error) and 80% power (20% beta error), 94 subjects would need to be enrolled (47 in each study arm). Expecting a 7.5% loss after randomization, 101 was the total number of subjects considered necessary to conduct the study.

outcome.title: Maternal Breastfeeding at 30 Days After Discharge
outcome.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).
outcome.time_frame: At 30 days after the infant hospital discharge

measure.title: Maternal Breastfeeding at 30 Days After Discharge
measure.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).

outcome.title: Maternal Breastfeeding 7-15 Days After Discharge
outcome.description: Maternal breastfeeding means: exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).
outcome.time_frame: At the first follow-up visit (7-15 days after discharge)
outcome.population: Analysis was by intention to treat (ITT)

measure.title: Maternal Breastfeeding 7-15 Days After Discharge
measure.description: Maternal breastfeeding means: exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).
measure.population: Analysis was by intention to treat (ITT)

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis: Music therapy does not increase the rate of maternal breastfeeding. Sample size: considering 75% as the expected rate at the time of the first follow-up visit and an absolute difference of 30% between groups, 95% confidence level (5% alpha error) and 80% power (20% beta error), 94 subjects would need to be enrolled (47 in each study arm). Expecting a 7.5% loss after randomization, 101 was the total number of subjects considered necessary to conduct the study.

outcome.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).

measure.description: Maternal breastfeeding means exclusive maternal breastfeeding, predominant maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associated to other liquid, except formula) and continuous maternal breastfeeding (maternal milk associate to other food, including formula).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
